solution_line_template: If Abel needs to travel {distance} miles going {abel_speed} miles per hour, this means it will take him {distance}/{abel_speed}=<<{distance}/{abel_speed}={abel_travel_hours}>>{abel_travel_hours} hours to get there.

If Alice needs to travel {distance} miles going {alice_speed} miles per hour, this means it will take her {distance}/{alice_speed}=<<{distance}/{alice_speed}={alice_travel_hours}>>{alice_travel_hours} hours to get there.

Since there are {minutes_per_hour} minutes in an hour, this means it will take Abel {abel_travel_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}= <<{abel_travel_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}={abel_travel_minutes}>>{abel_travel_minutes} minutes to arrive.
Similarly, this means it will take Alice {alice_travel_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}= <<{alice_travel_hours}*{minutes_per_hour}={alice_travel_minutes}>>{alice_travel_minutes} minutes to arrive.

This means Abel arrives {alice_travel_minutes}-{abel_travel_minutes}= <<{alice_travel_minutes}-{abel_travel_minutes}={time_difference_simultaneous}>>{time_difference_simultaneous} minutes before Alice if they both leave simultaneously.

However, since Abel had a head start of {abel_head_start_hours} hour, which is {minutes_per_hour} minutes, this means Abel arrives {time_difference_simultaneous} + {minutes_per_hour} = <<{time_difference_simultaneous}+{minutes_per_hour}={final_time_difference}>>{final_time_difference} minutes ahead of Alice
